title: [Too long but pls read] Today is not a victory. Here’s why.

replies.msg:
Carrie Lam’s purported withdrawal of the bill is not a victory. Here’s why.

Before passing your judgment on our refusal to accept Carrie Lam’s version of withdrawal of the bill, the first thing that we can all agree on is that we have come a long way from where we were three months ago. Little did we know then that the extradition bill would open up a Pandora’s box that set in motion the unfathomable that cost us whatever was left of our trust in the government, our respect for the police and our expectation of the “one country, two systems” policy.

Today, after months of condescendence, resistance and bloodshed, Carrie Lam has finally deigned to “move a motion” to withdraw the bill. What we thought would be a simple announcement at the Legco meeting to formally withdraw the bill turns out to be a heinous trick to pass the bill. As suggested by Carrie Lam, the government would move a motion at the second reading of the bill to be resumed when the Legco Council meeting reconvenes in October, which would then be voted by the Legco members consisting of a majority of the Pro-Beijing camp. If and when a simple majority of the Legco members objects to the motion to withdraw the bill, and the motions for second and third reading are agreed to (which would be an easily achievable task for them), the bill could eventually be passed by the Legco, letting Carrie Lam off the hook.

So no, we are not impressed by Carrie Lam’s feeble attempt to appease the public and the international community. We are on the brink of the abyss and, in all honesty, at the end of our tether, but we fear that if we give in now, if we give up now, we will risk having to lose everything we hold most dear. A timely quote from Mandela reminds us that courage is not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it. We only hope that you would give us the benefit of the doubt. Stand with us, fight along our side. Freedom comes at a price, but we never learnt just how high the cost was until three months ago. We will not yield until our five demands are met. We will not succumb.

Five demands, not one less.
